segment.source: Testing scenarios for enterprise data protection (EDP) (Windows 10)
segment.target: Testing scenarios for enterprise data protection (EDP) (Windows 10)

segment.source: We've come up with a list of suggested testing scenarios that you can use to test enterprise data protection (EDP) in your company.
segment.target: We've come up with a list of suggested testing scenarios that you can use to test enterprise data protection (EDP) in your company.

segment.source: Testing scenarios for enterprise data protection (EDP)
segment.target: Testing scenarios for enterprise data protection (EDP)

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Insider Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Insider Preview

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile Preview

segment.source: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]

segment.source: We've come up with a list of suggested testing scenarios that you can use to test enterprise data protection (EDP) in your company.
segment.target: We've come up with a list of suggested testing scenarios that you can use to test enterprise data protection (EDP) in your company.

segment.source: Testing scenarios
segment.target: Testing scenarios

segment.source: You can try any of the processes included in these scenarios, but you should focus on the ones that you might encounter in your organization.
segment.target: You can try any of the processes included in these scenarios, but you should focus on the ones that you might encounter in your organization.

segment.source: Scenario
segment.target: Scenario

segment.source: Processes
segment.target: Processes

segment.source: Automatically encrypt files from enterprise apps
segment.target: Automatically encrypt files from enterprise apps

segment.source: Start an unmodified (for example, EDP-unaware) line-of-business app that's on your Protected Apps list and then create, edit, write, and save files.
segment.target: Start an unmodified (for example, EDP-unaware) line-of-business app that's on your Protected Apps list and then create, edit, write, and save files.

segment.source: Make sure that all of the files you worked with from the EDP-unaware app are encrypted to your configured Enterprise Identity.
segment.target: Make sure that all of the files you worked with from the EDP-unaware app are encrypted to your configured Enterprise Identity.

segment.source: In some cases, you might need to close the file and wait a few moments for it to be automatically encrypted.
segment.target: In some cases, you might need to close the file and wait a few moments for it to be automatically encrypted.

segment.source: Open File Explorer and make sure your modified files are appearing with a Lock icon.
segment.target: Open File Explorer and make sure your modified files are appearing with a Lock icon.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Some file types, like .exe and .dll, along with some file paths, like and , are excluded from automatic encryption.
segment.target: Some file types, like .exe and .dll, along with some file paths, like and , are excluded from automatic encryption.

segment.source: Block enterprise data from non-enterprise apps
segment.target: Block enterprise data from non-enterprise apps

segment.source: Start an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list, and then try to open an enterprise-encrypted file.
segment.target: Start an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list, and then try to open an enterprise-encrypted file.

segment.source: The app shouldn't be able to access the file.
segment.target: The app shouldn't be able to access the file.

segment.source: Try double-clicking or tapping on the enterprise-encrypted file.
segment.target: Try double-clicking or tapping on the enterprise-encrypted file.

segment.source: If your default app association is an app not on your Protected Apps list, you should get an Access Denied error message.
segment.target: If your default app association is an app not on your Protected Apps list, you should get an Access Denied error message.

segment.source: Copy and paste from enterprise apps to non-enterprise apps
segment.target: Copy and paste from enterprise apps to non-enterprise apps

segment.source: Copy (CTRL+C) content from an app on your Protected Apps list, and then try to paste (CTRL+V) the content into an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Copy (CTRL+C) content from an app on your Protected Apps list, and then try to paste (CTRL+V) the content into an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: You should see an EDP-related warning box, asking you to click either Got it or Cancel.
segment.target: You should see an EDP-related warning box, asking you to click either Got it or Cancel.

segment.source: Click Cancel.
segment.target: Click Cancel.

segment.source: The content isn't pasted into the non-enterprise app.
segment.target: The content isn't pasted into the non-enterprise app.

segment.source: Repeat Step 1, but this time click Got it, and try to paste the content again.
segment.target: Repeat Step 1, but this time click Got it, and try to paste the content again.

segment.source: The content is pasted into the non-enterprise app.
segment.target: The content is pasted into the non-enterprise app.

segment.source: Try copying and pasting content between apps on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Try copying and pasting content between apps on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: The content should copy and paste between apps without any warning messages.
segment.target: The content should copy and paste between apps without any warning messages.

segment.source: Drag and drop from enterprise apps to non-enterprise apps
segment.target: Drag and drop from enterprise apps to non-enterprise apps

segment.source: Drag content from an app on your Protected Apps list, and then try to drop the content into an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Drag content from an app on your Protected Apps list, and then try to drop the content into an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: You should see an EDP-related warning box, asking you to click either Drag Anyway or Cancel.
segment.target: You should see an EDP-related warning box, asking you to click either Drag Anyway or Cancel.

segment.source: Click Cancel.
segment.target: Click Cancel.

segment.source: The content isn't dropped into the non-enterprise app.
segment.target: The content isn't dropped into the non-enterprise app.

segment.source: Repeat Step 1, but this time click Drag Anyway, and try to drop the content again.
segment.target: Repeat Step 1, but this time click Drag Anyway, and try to drop the content again.

segment.source: The content is dropped into the non-enterprise app.
segment.target: The content is dropped into the non-enterprise app.

segment.source: Try dragging and dropping content between apps on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Try dragging and dropping content between apps on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: The content should move between the apps without any warning messages.
segment.target: The content should move between the apps without any warning messages.

segment.source: Share between enterprise apps and non-enterprise apps
segment.target: Share between enterprise apps and non-enterprise apps

segment.source: Open an app on your Protected Apps list, like Microsoft Photos, and try to share content with an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list, like Facebook.
segment.target: Open an app on your Protected Apps list, like Microsoft Photos, and try to share content with an app that doesn't appear on your Protected Apps list, like Facebook.

segment.source: You should see an EDP-related warning box, asking you to click either Share Anyway or Cancel.
segment.target: You should see an EDP-related warning box, asking you to click either Share Anyway or Cancel.

segment.source: Click Cancel.
segment.target: Click Cancel.

segment.source: The content isn't shared into Facebook.
segment.target: The content isn't shared into Facebook.

segment.source: Repeat Step 1, but this time click Share Anyway, and try to share the content again.
segment.target: Repeat Step 1, but this time click Share Anyway, and try to share the content again.

segment.source: The content is shared into Facebook.
segment.target: The content is shared into Facebook.

segment.source: Try sharing content between apps on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Try sharing content between apps on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: The content should share between the apps without any warning messages.
segment.target: The content should share between the apps without any warning messages.

segment.source: Use the Encrypt to functionality
segment.target: Use the Encrypt to functionality

segment.source: Open File Explorer on the desktop, right-click a decrypted file, and then click Encrypt to from the Encrypt to menu.
segment.target: Open File Explorer on the desktop, right-click a decrypted file, and then click Encrypt to from the Encrypt to menu.

segment.source: EDP should encrypt the file to your Enterprise Identity.
segment.target: EDP should encrypt the file to your Enterprise Identity.

segment.source: Make sure that the newly encrypted file has a Lock icon.
segment.target: Make sure that the newly encrypted file has a Lock icon.

segment.source: In the Encrypted to column of File Explorer on the desktop, look for the enterprise ID value.
segment.target: In the Encrypted to column of File Explorer on the desktop, look for the enterprise ID value.

segment.source: Right-click the encrypted file, and then click Not encrypted from the Encrypt to menu.
segment.target: Right-click the encrypted file, and then click Not encrypted from the Encrypt to menu.

segment.source: The file should be decrypted and the Lock icon should disappear.
segment.target: The file should be decrypted and the Lock icon should disappear.

segment.source: Verify that Windows system components can use EDP
segment.target: Verify that Windows system components can use EDP

segment.source: Start Windows Journal and Internet Explorer 11, creating, editing, and saving files in both apps.
segment.target: Start Windows Journal and Internet Explorer 11, creating, editing, and saving files in both apps.

segment.source: Make sure that all of the files you worked with are encrypted to your configured Enterprise Identity.
segment.target: Make sure that all of the files you worked with are encrypted to your configured Enterprise Identity.

segment.source: In some cases, you might need to close the file and wait a few moments for it to be automatically encrypted.
segment.target: In some cases, you might need to close the file and wait a few moments for it to be automatically encrypted.

segment.source: Open File Explorer and make sure your modified files are appearing with a Lock icon
segment.target: Open File Explorer and make sure your modified files are appearing with a Lock icon

segment.source: Try copying and pasting, dragging and dropping, and sharing using these apps with other apps that appear both on and off the Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Try copying and pasting, dragging and dropping, and sharing using these apps with other apps that appear both on and off the Protected Apps list.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Most Windows-signed components like Windows Explorer (when running in the user’s context), should have access to enterprise data.
segment.target: Most Windows-signed components like Windows Explorer (when running in the user’s context), should have access to enterprise data.

segment.source: A few notable exceptions include some of the user-facing in-box apps, like Wordpad, Notepad, and Microsoft Paint.
segment.target: A few notable exceptions include some of the user-facing in-box apps, like Wordpad, Notepad, and Microsoft Paint.

segment.source: These apps don't have access by default, but can be added to your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: These apps don't have access by default, but can be added to your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: Use EDP on FAT/exFAT systems
segment.target: Use EDP on FAT/exFAT systems

segment.source: Start an app that uses the FAT or exFAT file system and appears on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Start an app that uses the FAT or exFAT file system and appears on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: Create, edit, write, save, and move files.
segment.target: Create, edit, write, save, and move files.

segment.source: Basic file and folder operations like copy, move, rename, delete, and so on, should work properly on encrypted files.
segment.target: Basic file and folder operations like copy, move, rename, delete, and so on, should work properly on encrypted files.

segment.source: Try copying and moving files or folders between apps that use NTFS, FAT and exFAT file systems.
segment.target: Try copying and moving files or folders between apps that use NTFS, FAT and exFAT file systems.

segment.source: Use EDP on NTFS systems
segment.target: Use EDP on NTFS systems

segment.source: Start an app that uses the NTFS file system and appears on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: Start an app that uses the NTFS file system and appears on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: Create, edit, write, save, and move files.
segment.target: Create, edit, write, save, and move files.

segment.source: Basic file and folder operations like copy, move, rename, delete, and so on, should work properly on encrypted files.
segment.target: Basic file and folder operations like copy, move, rename, delete, and so on, should work properly on encrypted files.

segment.source: Try copying and moving files or folders between apps that use NTFS, FAT and exFAT file systems.
segment.target: Try copying and moving files or folders between apps that use NTFS, FAT and exFAT file systems.

segment.source: Unenroll client devices from EDP
segment.target: Unenroll client devices from EDP

segment.source: Unenroll a device from EDP by going to Settings, click Accounts, click Work, click the name of the device you want to unenroll, and then click Remove.
segment.target: Unenroll a device from EDP by going to Settings, click Accounts, click Work, click the name of the device you want to unenroll, and then click Remove.

segment.source: The device should be removed and all of the enterprise content for that managed account should be gone.
segment.target: The device should be removed and all of the enterprise content for that managed account should be gone.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Unenrolling a device revokes and erases all of the enterprise data for the managed account.
segment.target: Unenrolling a device revokes and erases all of the enterprise data for the managed account.

segment.source: Verify that app content is protected when a Windows 10 Mobile phone is locked
segment.target: Verify that app content is protected when a Windows 10 Mobile phone is locked

segment.source: Check that protected app data doesn't appear on the Lock screen of a Windows 10 Mobile phone
segment.target: Check that protected app data doesn't appear on the Lock screen of a Windows 10 Mobile phone
